Please submit your information via online form, by email at info@thriveforlife.org, or by calling to refer yourself or your client/loved one. To be eligible, you must be post-conviction and have served your sentence, or be on parole. The state of detention is irrelevant, and the parole transfer via Interstate Compact is available to New York State. Because most clients live in Ignacio or Abraham House while in college, the proximity of schools does not allow for any sex offender status of the clients, and referrals can be made to Fortune Society.\nThey also have a Milwaukee location.

Any individual who has served any amount of time in NYS jails and prisons can request their case manager, focusing on justice-involved people, to refer them here. Immigration status does not matter. If you are a non-citizen with a criminal record, please see if you might be at risk of deportation. If you have been convicted of or have a pending charge of sexual violence or arson, you may not reside here. Ignacio's house has 1 person per room, and Abraham's House has 2 people per room. Only male clients are served. By New York State law, you may identify with whichever gender you choose and may apply to these services accordingly, although your safety is not guaranteed. \nAny people with pending charges, except sex offenders, can utilize off-site support services by participating in 4 hours of community service, weekly Moral Reconation Therapy (MRT), and individual counseling twice a week in exchange for a letter of recommendation to the court.

You must have a valid social security number and employment eligibility if you are a non-citizen to gain employment. If you are a non-citizen, you might be subject to removal if at least one of your mandatory (even if it is suspended or reduced) sentences is over one year or the number of counts amounts to more than one year of jail time. Crimes against moral turpitude, like theft or engagement in sex work, can make you inadmissible if you confess to an immigration official about that. You should only contact them if you need representation concerning eviction, nonpayment, or holdover. Other matters are not being considered as the Legal Aid Society is over capacity. There is no guarantee they will be able to represent you. When you call the switchboard of the Legal Aid Society, your information will be taken, and you will receive a callback.\n\nAlternatively, you may attend your first court/hearing date, either virtually or in person, whichever is indicated, to attempt to get connected with a legal service provider. It is your right to have your case go through the Right to Counsel program to determine if you are eligible for representation or advice.

organization_name: The HOPE Program (FKA Sustainable South Bronx)
text:
� Virtual and in-person sessions are available; sign up online. Please bring a photo ID. � After an info session, you can apply for :
 � HOPEworks is a seven-week program that helps participants succeed in the job market and navigate careers in various fields through cover letter and resume writing, computer skills, interview prep, basic math and English literacy, and workplace soft skills such as public speaking and conflict resolution.
 � Intervine is a ten-week transitional employment program that pays participants to engage in hands-on learning through green infrastructure projects across the city while learning critical job skills.
 � Sustainable South Bronx is a fourteen-week program that prepares job seekers for green infrastructure and maintenance careers through classroom-based learning, industry-recognized certifications, hands-on community greening projects, and job application skills.
 � NYC �CoolRoofs is a ten-week transitional employment program that pays participants to coat rooftops in a reflective material that reduces their energy output. Participants gain hands-on experience while helping to make New York City more sustainable.
 � Green and Clean HVAC Training is an eleven-week program preparing job seekers for careers in high-efficiency heating, ventilation, and air conditioning, with a focus on heat pumps and energy-efficient technology.

Provides health literacy and self-efficacy for individuals at high risk for HIV/HCV/STIs and HIV-infected persons. Psychosocial support counseling is offered to assess clients� mental health needs and to provide counseling to encourage clients to access additional services.

Transitional Housing Program (THP) provides three units of male-only congregate transitional housing in Brooklyn. This service is offered to single men living with HIV/AIDS. The THP works with case management and mental health programs to place clients in THP congregate apartments. In addition to housing, clients receive counseling, case management, medical transportation, and other services through the After Hours Project office.

Provides access to medical treatment and care through the provision of medical transportation. MetroCards for buses and subways and mobile van services are provided to transport clients to and from HIV-related medical care and other supportive service appointments.
A licensed clinical social worker works with clients to address the underlying causes of high-risk behavior, such as a history of sexual assault, physical or mental abuse, and other trauma.

AHP promotes substance users' overall health and well-being by increasing connection to care and drug treatment services. This program also increases the availability of HIV testing and reduction services by expanding mobile rapid services.

organization_name: Utopia Resource Center (URC) Greater New York, Inc.
text:
1. Early Head Start: This program provides low-income families with comprehensive early childhood education and support services. Infants, toddlers, and pregnant women have access to high-quality education.

2. Head Start: This federal program provides early childhood education and social services to income-eligible children and their families. Children receive educational support and development opportunities to prepare them for kindergarten.

3. Child Care Services: This program helps parents find suitable childcare arrangements. They work closely with community organizations and providers to ensure that parents have access to quality care for their children.

4. Parenting Support: They provide parenting support programs, workshops, and resources to equip parents with the skills and tools they need to support their child's development and overall well-being. 5. Adult Literacy Programs: They provide adult literacy classes to adults who have limited reading or writing skills. Programs are designed to develop foundational literacy skills, enhance communication skills, and improve overall literacy proficiency.

6. Early Childhood Literacy Programs: These programs incorporate literacy activities, storytelling, and book distribution to encourage a love for reading from an early age.

organization_name: Utopia Resource Center (URC) Greater New York, Inc.
text:
1. Job Training: They offer training programs tailored to various industries, including healthcare and education. The training programs provide individuals with the necessary skills and knowledge to secure employment.

\n2. Career Counseling: Career counselors help individuals explore their career options, develop job search strategies, and navigate the employment landscape. They provide guidance and support throughout the entire employment journey.

organization_name: Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York (CIDNY)
text:
CIDNY has three offices across NYC. It can serve NYC residents with disabilities regardless of immigration status (some reimbursement and benefit programs are tied to SSDI and are unavailable to some non-citizens). Parental consent is required for underage participants. Many programs are tied to employment, so a valid work permit or US citizenship/residency is required. 
Services Include* and are available in many languages with accommodation for the deaf, blind, and people with other challenges. All facilities are ADA-compliant:
� Information and referral, nutritional outreach, job readiness, peer support, and independent living (for example, during readjustment after returning home from a nursing facility)
� Free training, reasonable accommodation, transportation expense reimbursement, affordable housing, and benefits (compensated through Social Security only for people with a qualified disability, income, and immigration status)
*People convicted of a sex crime are not served.

Schedule:
 � Guests should plan to arrive between 4:00 PM and 5:00 PM.
 � Upon arrival, participants are offered snacks, tea, and a communal prayer session, followed by dinner.
 � Residents take turns showering in the evening.
 � A breathalyzer test is administered upon entry each night to ensure sobriety. � Phone Policy:
 � Personal phones are collected and stored downstairs, where they are also charged overnight. � Sleeping Arrangements:
 � Each sleeping area accommodates up to 10 beds per room.
 � Daily Routine: � Wake-up is at 5:00 AM.
 � Breakfast is served at 6:00 AM.
 � All guests must leave the facility by 6:30 AM each morning. � Program Duration:
 � Guests may stay for up to 21 consecutive days.
 � If a participant misses a night without calling ahead, they forfeit that night.
 � If they miss two nights without communication, they lose their spot in the program.
 � Guests are permitted to stay out for up to 2 nights during the 21-day period and can be re-admitted for one additional 21-day cycle if needed. � Seasonal Availability:
 � The program operates from June 10 through September 15 each year.

organization_name: Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York (CIDNY)
text:
CIDNY has three offices across NYC. Residents 14 and older (parental consent is required for underage participants) of any NYC borough with disabilities, regardless of immigration status (some reimbursement and benefit programs are tied to SSDI and are unavailable to some non-citizens) can be served. Many programs are tied to employment, so a valid work permit, Green Card, or US citizenship is required. 
Services Include* and are available in many languages with accommodation for the deaf, blind, and people with other challenges. All facilities are ADA-compliant:
� Information and referral, nutritional outreach, job readiness, peer support, and independent living (for example, during readjustment after returning home from a nursing facility)
� Free training, reasonable accommodation, transportation expense reimbursement, affordable housing, and benefits (compensated through Social Security only for people with a qualified disability, income, and immigration status)
* People convicted of a sex crime are not served.
Education for 3-5-year olds. Spanish language is available as well as support for children with IEP.

You must leave after breakfast at 8:00 AM, but can return during the day center hours, Monday through Friday, from 10:00 AM to 2:00 PM. You must return by curfew at 3:30 PM. It has been reported that after the first week, they enter you in a lottery, when you are competing with other people for a bed for the coming week, and so on.

The summer camp (CLUE) runs from July to August (one month) for grades 1 through 6. The teen center runs during the school year for grades 6 through 12. Please call directly to find out the actual dates and times.

Winter clothing is available from the beginning of November to the end of March. One visit per person, per month is permitted.\n\nEmail rmm@rmmnyc.org or call (212) 594-4464 to find the exact start and end dates.

Client choice of groceries, depending on availability. This service is typically available on the 1st and 3rd Saturday of the month.
